The distance between the box-strainer and the rectangular frame is adjustable so that the level at which water is drawn can be raised or lowered.""Article: Puerto Rican Inventor Develops Floating Strainer"; US Fed News Service, Including US State News; July 12, 2007 ===Soft drinks=== [[File:AngelRiveroMendez.png|125x150px|right|thumb|Angel Rivero]] ::'''[[Ángel Rivero Méndez]]''' (1856–1930) was a soldier, writer, journalist and a businessman who is credited with inventing the "Kola Champagne" a [[soft drink]].[http://perso.wanadoo.es/padron/rivero/ Spanish American War -Rivero Biography] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090111061510/http://perso.wanadoo.es/padron/rivero/ |date=January 11, 2009 }}, Retrieved October 4, 2008[http://home.coqui.net/sarrasin/index.htm Spanish American War in Puerto Rico], Retrieved October 4, 2008 After Rivero retired from the military, he founded the "Fabrica Polo Norte" (North Pole Factory) a soft drink company. Rivero is credited with the invention and elaboration of the "Kola Champagne" soda. Kola Champagne became, and still is, a very popular drink in Puerto Rico. It is also elaborated and sold in other countries, such as the United States, [[Colombia]], [[Jamaica]] and Mexico. {{clear}} ==See also== {{Portal|Puerto Rico|Biography|Puerto Rico/Did you know-Puerto Rico?}} {{History of science and technology in the United States}} '''Timelines of United States inventions''' * [[Timeline of United States inventions (before 1890)]] * [[Timeline of United States inventions (1890–1945)]] * [[Timeline of United States inventions (1946–1991)]] * [[Timeline of United States inventions (after 1991)]] '''Related topics''' * {{Hatnote|To view U.S. inventions, please see [[Timeline of United States inventions]].}} * [[School of Tropical Medicine (Puerto Rico)|School of Tropical Medicine]] * [[History of United States patent law]] * [[Lemelson Foundation]] * [[Lemelson–MIT Prize]] * [[List of African American inventors and scientists]] * [[List of famous Puerto Ricans]] * [[List of inventors killed by their own inventions]] * [[List of prolific inventors]] * [[List of Puerto Ricans in the United States Space Program]] * [[NASA spinoff]] * [[National Inventors Hall of Fame]] * [[Native American contributions]] * [[Science and technology in the United States]] * [[Technological and industrial history of the United States]] * [[Timeline of United States discoveries]] * [[United States Patent and Trademark Office]] * [[United States patent law]] * [[Yankee ingenuity]] * [[History of women in Puerto Rico]] {{clear}} ==References== {{reflist|30em}} ==Further reading== * [http://www.cienciapr.org ''Ciencia Puerto Rico.''] ** A website dedicated to the global Puerto Rican scientific community. Contains profiles of thousands of living Puerto Rican scientists. * [http://www.cienciapr.org/en/general-public/news ''News Stories.''] ** A collection of news stories related to science in Puerto Rico or by Puerto Rican scientists {{Inventions}} {{United States topics}} * [[Puerto Rican citizenship]] * [[Outline of Puerto Rico]] * [[Cultural diversity in Puerto Rico]] **[[Corsican immigration to Puerto Rico]] **[[French immigration to Puerto Rico]] **[[Crypto-Judaism]] **[[German immigration to Puerto Rico]] **[[Irish immigration to Puerto Rico]] **[[Royal Decree of Graces of 1815]] * [[Index of Puerto Rico-related articles]] * [[History of women in Puerto Rico]] * [[Military history of Puerto Rico]] * [[National Register of Historic Places listings in Puerto Rico]] * [[51st state|51-star flag]] {{DEFAULTSORT:List Of Puerto Rican Scientists And Inventors}} [[Category:Puerto Rican scientists|*]] [[Category:Lists of Puerto Rican people by occupation|Scientists]] [[Category:Lists of inventors|Puerto Rican]] [[Category:American inventors|*]] [[Category:Lists of American people by occupation|Scientists, Puerto Rico]] [[Category:Puerto Rican inventors]]

revision.comment: /* Historic */

page.title: List of nearest terrestrial exoplanet candidates

revision.comment: Reverted edits by [[Special:Contributions/173.197.215.242|173.197.215.242]] ([[User talk:173.197.215.242|talk]]) ([[WP:HG|HG]]) (3.4.4)
revision.text:
This '''list of nearest space terrestrial exoplanets candidates''' contains possible [[Terrestrial planet|terrestrial]] ("rocky") [[exoplanet]]s spaced at a distance of up to 50 [[light-year]]s from the [[Solar System]], ordered by increasing distance.{{citation | display-authors=1 | last1=Pepe | first1=F. | last2=Lovis | first2=C. | last3=Ségransan | first3=D. | last4=Benz | first4=W. |last5=Bouchy | first5=F. | last6=Dumusque | first6=X. | last7=Mayor | first7=M. | last8=Queloz | first8=M. | last9=Queloz | first9=D. | last10=Udry | first10=S. |title=The HARPS search for Earth-like planets in the habitable zone: I – Very low-mass planets around HD20794, HD85512 and HD192310 | journal=Astronomy & Astrophysics | volume=534 | pages=A58 | date=2011 | arxiv=1108.3447 | bibcode=2011A&A...534A..58P | doi=10.1051/0004-6361/201117055 }}{{citation | first1=Jean | last1=Schneider | publisher=Paris Observatory | title=Star: HD 20794 | work=Extrasolar Planets Encyclopaedia |url=http://exoplanet.eu/star.php?st=HD+20794 | accessdate=2011-12-05 }}{{Cite journal|last= Tuomi, Anglada-Escude, Gerlach, Jones, Reiners, Rivera, Vogt, Butler|first= Mikko, Guillem, Enrico, Hugh R. R., Ansgar, Eugenio J., Steven S., R. Paul|authorlink= |arxiv= 1211.1617v1|title= Habitable-zone super-Earth candidate in a six-planet system around the K2.5V star HD 40307|journal= Astronomy & Astrophysics|volume= 549|pages= A48|date= 2012|version= |last2= Anglada-Escude|first2= Guillem|last3= Gerlach|first3= Enrico|last4= Jones|first4= Hugh R. R.|last5= Reiners|first5= Ansgar|last6= Rivera|first6= Eugenio J.|last7= Vogt|first7= Steven S.|last8= Paul Butler|first8= R.|doi= 10.1051/0004-6361/201220268|bibcode=2013A&A...549A..48T}} They may be composed primarily of [[silicate]] [[Rock (geology)|rock]]s and/or [[metal]]s. Within the [[Solar System]], the terrestrial planets are the [[Solar System#Inner planets|inner planets]] closest to the [[Sun]]. == Exoplanets discovered (incomplete)== This list is incomplete, currently containing 34 exoplanets, 11 of which probably lie inside their star's [[habitable zone]]. There are roughly 2,000 stars at a distance of up to 50 light-years from the Solar System{{cite web|url=http://www.atlasoftheuniverse.com/50lys.html|title=Stars within 50 light years|publisher=|accessdate=3 October 2015}} (64 of them are yellow-orange [[G-type star|"G" stars]] like our Sun{{cite web|url=http://www.solstation.com/stars3/100-gs.htm|title=G stars within 100 light-years|publisher=|accessdate=3 October 2015}}). As many as 15% of them can have Earth-sized planets in the habitable zones.{{Cite journal|arxiv=1403.0430|title= Bayesian search for low-mass planets around nearby M dwarfs. Estimates for occurrence rate based on global detectability statistics|journal= Monthly Notices of the Royal Astronomical Society|volume= 441|issue= 2|pages= 1545–1569|publisher=|last1= Tuomi|first1= Mikko|last2= Jones|first2= Hugh R. A.|last3= Barnes|first3= John R.|last4= Anglada-Escudé|first4= Guillem|last5= Jenkins|first5= James S.|year= 2014|doi= 10.1093/mnras/stu358|bibcode = 2014MNRAS.441.1545T }} On November 4, 2013, astronomers reported, based on [[Kepler (spacecraft)|''Kepler'' space mission]] data, that there could be as many as 40 billion [[Terrestrial planet|Earth-sized]] [[extrasolar planets|planets]] orbiting in the [[habitable zone]]s of [[sun-like|sun-like stars]] and [[red dwarf stars]] within the [[Milky Way Galaxy]].{{cite news |last=Overbye |first=Dennis|title=Far-Off Planets Like the Earth Dot the Galaxy|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2013/11/05/science/cosmic-census-finds-billions-of-planets-that-could-be-like-earth.html |date=November 4, 2013 |work=[[New York Times]] |accessdate=November 5, 2013 }}{{cite journal |last1=Petigura |first1=Eric A.|last2=Howard |first2=Andrew W. |last3=Marcy |first3=Geoffrey W. |title=Prevalence of Earth-size planets orbiting Sun-like stars|url=http://www.pnas.org/content/early/2013/10/31/1319909110 |date=October 31, 2013 |journal=[[Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the United States of America]]|volume=110|issue=48|pages=19273–19278|doi=10.1073/pnas.1319909110 |accessdate=November 5, 2013 |arxiv = 1311.6806 |bibcode = 2013PNAS..11019273P |pmid=24191033 |pmc=3845182}} 11 billion of these estimated planets may be orbiting sun-like stars.{{cite news |last=Khan |first=Amina |title=Milky Way may host billions of Earth-size planets |url=http://www.latimes.com/science/la-sci-earth-like-planets-20131105,0,2673237.story |date=November 4, 2013 |work=[[Los Angeles Times]] |accessdate=November 5, 2013 }} The nearest such planet may be as close as 12 light-years away. On August 24, 2016, astronomers announced the discovery of a rocky planet in the habitable zone of [[Proxima Centauri]], the closest star to Earth. Called [[Proxima b]], the planet is 1.3 times the mass of Earth and has an orbital period of roughly 11.2 Earth days.{{cite journal|last1=Anglada-Escudé|first1=Guillem|title=A terrestrial planet candidate in a temperate orbit around Proxima Centauri|journal=Nature|date=August 24, 2016|url=http://www.eso.org/public/archives/releases/sciencepapers/eso1629/eso1629a.pdf|doi=10.1038/nature19106|pmid=27558064|volume=536|issue=7617|pages=437–40|arxiv = 1609.03449 |bibcode = 2016Natur.536..437A }} However Proxima Centauri’s classification as a red dwarf casts doubts on the habitability of any exoplanets in its orbit due to low stellar flux, high probability of tidal locking, small circumstellar habitable zones and high stellar variation. Another likely candidate is [[Alpha Centauri]], Earth’s nearest Sun-like star system 4.37 light years away. Estimates place the probability of finding a habitable planet around Alpha Centauri A or B at roughly 85%.{{cite web|last1=Billings|first1=Lee|title=Miniature Space Telescope Could Boost the Hunt for "Earth Proxima"| url=http://www.scientificamerican.com/article/miniature-space-telescope-could-boost-the-hunt-for-earth-proxima-video|website=Scientific American}} Alpha Centauri is the target of several exoplanet-finding missions, including [[Breakthrough Starshot]] and Mission Centaur, the latter of which is chronicled in the 2016 documentary film, "The Search for Earth Proxima."{{cite web|title=The Search for Earth Proxima|url=https://www.theatlantic.com/video/index/492266/the-search-for-earth-proxima|website=The Atlantic}} ==Table== {| class="wikipedia sortable" border=1 cellspacing=0 cellpadding=2 align=center style="text-align:center; background:#f0f0f0; border-collapse:collapse; margin-left: 0; margin-right: auto;" ! |'''Name''' ! class="unsortable" |''' Image (artist's concept) ''' ! |'''{{abbr|M⊕|Mass (in Earth masses)}}''' ! |'''{{abbr|R⊕|Radius (in Earth radii)}}''' ! |'''{{abbr|g|Surface gravity (1 - standard Earth gravity)}}''' ! |'''{{abbr|Ts|Surface temperature}}''' ! |'''{{abbr|''a''|Semi-major axis in astronomical units}}''' ! |'''{{abbr|''e''|Orbital eccentricity}}''' ! class="unsortable" |{{abbr|[s]|Main source}} ! |'''{{abbr|D|Distance from the Sun in lightyears}}''' |- | [[Proxima Centauri b]]||[[File:Artist’s impression of Proxima Centauri b shown hypothetically as an arid rocky super-earth.jpg|200px|center]]||≥1.27 || ~1.1|| || {{free|234 K

Sources in the "Main source" column confirm the ''possibility'' of terrestrial composition. In September 2012, the discovery of two planets orbiting [[Gliese 163]]{{cite web|author=Staff |title=LHS 188 -- High proper-motion Star |url=http://simbad.u-strasbg.fr/simbad/sim-id?Ident=HIP+19394 |date=September 20, 2012 |publisher=[[Centre de données astronomiques de Strasbourg]](Strasbourg astronomical Data Center) |accessdate=September 20, 2012 }} was announced.{{cite web |last=Méndez |first=Abel |title=A Hot Potential Habitable Exoplanet around Gliese 163|url=http://phl.upr.edu/press-releases/ahotpotentialhabitableexoplanetaroundgliese163 |date=August 29, 2012|publisher=[[University of Puerto Rico at Arecibo]] (Planetary Habitability Laboratory)|accessdate=September 20, 2012 }}{{cite web |last=Redd |first = Nola Taylor|title=Newfound Alien Planet a Top Contender to Host Life|url=http://www.space.com/17684-alien-planet-gliese-163c-extraterrestrial-life.html|date=September 20, 2012|publisher=[[Space.com]] |accessdate=September 20, 2012 }} One of the planets, [[Gliese 163 c]], about 6.9 times the mass of Earth and somewhat hotter, was considered to be within the [[habitable zone]], but is probably not terrestrial. In May 2016, the finding of three earth-like planets of ultracool dwarf [[TRAPPIST-1]] has been released. ==Statistics== {| class="sortable wikitable" |+ Distance from the Solar System |- ! scope="col" |Distance ! scope="col" |Lying within
the habitable zone ! scope="col" |All |- !< 10 light-years | style="text-align:center;"|0 (2?) | style="text-align:center;"|2 systems |- ! < 20 light-years | style="text-align:center;"|6 | style="text-align:center;"|15 |- ! < 30 light-years | style="text-align:center;"|8 | style="text-align:center;"|22 |- ! < 40 light-years | style="text-align:center;"|10 | style="text-align:center;"|24 |- ! < 50 light-years | style="text-align:center;"|11 | style="text-align:center;"|31 |} '''Note''': in most cases the composition of the atmosphere and atmosphere pressure of exoplanets are unknown, so surface temperatures are estimates based on computer models and expert opinions. == See also == {{portal|Astronomy|Lists}} * [[Interstellar travel]] * [[List of exoplanetary host stars]] * [[List of multiplanetary systems]] * [[List of nearest exoplanets]] * [[List of nearest stars and brown dwarfs]] * [[List of potentially habitable exoplanets]] * [[Solar analog#Solar twin|List of Solar twins]] == References == {{Reflist|30em}} == Links == * [http://www.solstation.com/planets/super-earths.htm Super-Earth Candidates in or near Habitable Zone] {{exoplanet}} [[Category:Planetary systems|*List]] [[Category:Lists of superlatives in astronomy|Exoplanets, nearest terrestrial candidates]] [[Category:Lists of exoplanets|Nearest terrestrial candidates]]

page.title: List of state visits made by Elizabeth II

revision.comment: Moving from [[Category:Diplomatic visits by heads of state]] to [[Category:Lists of diplomatic visits by heads of state]] using [[c:Help:Cat-a-lot|Cat-a-lot]]
revision.text:
[[File:Visits by Elizabeth II.svg|thumb|300px|Overseas trips made by Elizabeth II. A darker colour corresponds to a greater number of visits]] Since ascending the throne in 1952, [[Queen Elizabeth II]] has undertaken a number of state and official visits<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.royal.uk/sites/default/files/media/state_visits_paid_by_the_queen_with_the_duke_of_edinburgh_2.pdf |title=Outward State visits since 1955 |accessdate=22 April 2016}}</ref> as well as [[List of Commonwealth visits made by Queen Elizabeth II|trips throughout the Commonwealth]], making her the most widely travelled [[head of state]] in history. The Queen does not require a [[British passport]] for travelling overseas, as all British passports are issued in her name.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.royal.uk/passports|title=Passports|date=15 January 2016|publisher=Official website of the royal family}}</ref>
As the sovereign of more than one independent state, Elizabeth II has represented both Canada and the United Kingdom on [[state visit]]s, though the former on just two occasions. For the countries where Elizabeth II is sovereign, other than the United Kingdom, the relevant [[Governor-General#Independent Commonwealth realms|governor-general]] will usually carry out state visits on the Queen's behalf.
==As Queen of Canada== {| class="wikitable sortable" border="1" style="margin: 1em auto 1em auto" ! class="unsortable" | Date !! revision.text:
{{notability|date=September 2018}} '''Ljubinka Nikolić''' (born 1964) is a [[Serbia]]n geologist and geographer who was selected to be part of the [[Mars One]] project.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.srbijadanas.com/clanak/srbija-do-marsa-beogradanka-korak-blize-putovanju-na-crvenu-planetu-video-17-02-2015|title=Srbija do Marsa: Beograđanka korak bliže putovanju na Crvenu planetu (VIDEO)|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.srbijadanas.com/clanak/srpkinja-koja-ide-na-mars-ponecu-samo-tri-stvari-11-04-2015|title=SRPKINJA KOJA IDE NA MARS: Poneću samo tri stvari!|publisher=}}</ref> She, along with 99 other contenders, has been shortlisted to be one of the first humans to land on Mars. She believes that "The Red planet will be the next home for humanity".<ref name="mars-one.com">{{cite web|url=https://community.mars-one.com/profile/9c145cad-b668-4d25-9317-7e943c6b7fc9|title=Ljubinka Nikolic - Mars One Community Platform|website=Mars One Community Platform}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.srbijadanas.com/clanak/neverovatno-ali-istinito-evo-kada-ce-biti-moguce-preseliti-se-i-ziveti-na-marsu-31-08-2015|title=NEVEROVATNO, ALI ISTINITO: Evo kada će biti moguće preseliti se i živeti na MARSU!|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.sbs.com.au/yourlanguage/serbian/en/audiotrack/ljubinka-hoping-one-way-ticket-mars|title=Ljubinka is hoping for one-way ticket to Mars|publisher=}}</ref>
Originally from [[Belgrade]], Nikolić has a bachelors in geological engineering from the [[University of Belgrade]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.glassrpske.com/plus/intervju/Ljubinka-Nikolic-srpski-kandidata-za-odlazak-na-Mars-za-Glas-Srpske-Kada-nesto-zelis-ni-Mars-nije-daleko/lat/175836.html|title=Ljubinka Nikolić, srpski kandidata za odlazak na Mars, za Glas Srpske: Kada nešto želiš, ni Mars nije daleko|publisher=}}</ref> She also has a master’s in geography from [[New York City|New York]]'s [[Hunter College]] and another master's in interior decoration, which she obtained from the Florence Design Academy in [[Italy]].<ref name="mars-one.com"/><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.slobodnaevropa.org/a/ljubinka-nikolic-kako-sam-odlucila-da-napustim-zemlju-i-odem-na-mars/26927585.html|title=Ljubinka Nikolić: Kako sam odlučila da napustim Zemlju i odem na Mars|website=Radio Slobodna Evropa}}</ref>
==References== <references /> {{DEFAULTSORT:Nikolic, Ljubinka}} {{authority control}} [[Category:1964 births]] [[Category:University of Belgrade alumni]] [[Category:Hunter College alumni]] [[Category:Serbian geographers]] [[Category:Serbian geologists]] [[Category:Serbian designers]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Women geologists]] [[Category:Women geographers]] [[Category:People from Belgrade]] [[Category:Mars One]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox scientist |name = Maurits Lindström |image = |image_size = |caption = |birth_date = {{birth date|df=yes|1932|05|10}} |birth_place = |death_date = {{death date and age|2009|11|14|1932|05|10|df=y}} |death_place = |residence = Sweden |citizenship = Sweden |nationality = Swedish |field = [[Geology]], [[Paleontology]], [[Meteoritics]] |work_institutions = [[Stockholm University]] |alma_mater = |doctoral_advisor = |father = |known_for = |influences = |influenced = |prizes = [[Naturvetarna|Årets geolog]]
[[Pander Society|Pander Medal]] |religion = |footnotes = |signature = }} '''Maurits Lindström''' (10 May 1932 – 14 November 2009) was a Swedish geologist and paleontologist. Lindströms initial work was divided among two topics [[conodont]] paleontology and the structural geology of the [[Scandinavian Caledonides]] in [[Lapland (Sweden)|Lappland]].{{cite journal |last1=Bergström |first1=Stig M.|last2=Bergström |first2=Jan |last3=Kumpulainen |first3=Risto|last4=Ormö |first4=Jens|last5=Sturkell |first5=Erik |date=2007 |title=Maurits Lindström – A renaissance geoscientist |journal=[[GFF (journal)|GFF]] |volume=129 |issue=2 |pages=65–70 |doi=10.1080/11035890701292065 }} In [[1970 in paleontology|1970]], he described the conodont families [[Cordylodontidae]], [[Gondolellidae]], [[Proconodontidae]] and [[Rhipidognathidae]].A suprageneric taxonomy of the conodonts. Maurits Lindström, Lethaia, Volume 3, Issue 4, pages 427–445, October 1970, {{doi|10.1111/j.1502-3931.1970.tb00834.x}} In [[1971 in paleontology|1971]], he described the conodont genera ''[[Baltoniodus]]'', ''[[Microzarkodina]]'' and ''[[Paracordylodus]]''.Vom Anfang, Hochstand und Ende eines Epikontinentalmeeres. Maurits Lindström, Geologische Rundschau, March 1971, Volume 60, Issue 2, pages 419-438, {{doi|10.1007/BF02000464}} Lindström published conodont studies up to 1987 after which he only supervised students working with conodonts. In the late 1980s Lindström begun to study ancient [[impact crater]]s in the [[Baltic Shield|Fennoscandian Shield]]. His studies have confirmed earlier speculations that [[Tvären]] and [[Lockne crater|Lockne]] are craters. == Awards and tributes == In 1985 he became member of the [[Royal Swedish Academy of Sciences]] and in 2009 he was awarded the prize "Årets geolog" (Geologist of the Year) by Geosektionen of [[Naturvetarna]].[http://www.naturvetarna.se/Medlem/Professionsforeningar/Geosektionen/Handlingar/ Geosektionens handlingar] He received the Pander Medal awarded by the [[Pander Society]], an informal organisation founded in 1967 for the promotion of the study of conodont palaeontology. ==References== {{reflist}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Lindstrom, Maurits}} [[Category:1932 births]] [[Category:2009 deaths]] [[Category:Members of the Royal Swedish Academy of Sciences]] [[Category:Swedish geologists]] [[Category:Swedish paleontologists]] [[Category:Conodont specialists]] [[Category:Meteorite researchers]] {{Sweden-scientist-stub}} {{Geologist-stub}}

revision.text:
[[File:Nano-FTIR-setup-schematics.jpg|alt=nano-FTIR schematics|thumb|341x341px|The schematic representation of a nano-FTIR system with a broadband infrared source.]] '''Nano-FTIR''' ('''nanoscale Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy''') is a [[Scanning probe microscopy|scanning probe technique]] that can be considered as a combination of two techniques: [[Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy]] (FTIR) and [[near-field scanning optical microscope|scattering-type scanning near-field optical microscopy]] (s-SNOM). As s-SNOM, nano-FTIR is based on [[atomic-force microscopy]] (AFM), where a sharp tip is illuminated by an external light source and the tip-scattered light (typically back-scattered) is detected as a function of tip position. A typical nano-FTIR setup thus consists of an atomic force microscope, a broadband infrared light source used for tip illumination, and a [[Michelson interferometer]] acting as [[Fourier transform spectroscopy|Fourier transform spectrometer]]. In nano-FTIR, the sample stage is placed in one of the interferometer arms, which allows for recording both amplitude and phase of the detected light (unlike conventional FTIR that normally does not yield phase information). Scanning the tip allows for performing [[hyperspectral imaging]] (i.e. complete spectrum at every pixel of the scanned area) with nanoscale spatial resolution determined by the tip apex size. The use of broadband infrared sources enables the acquisition of continuous spectra, which is a distinctive feature of nano-FTIR compared to s-SNOM. Nano-FTIR is capable of performing [[Infrared spectroscopy|infrared (IR) spectroscopy]] of materials in ultrasmall quantities and with nanoscale spatial resolution.<ref name=":11">{{Cite journal|last=Amarie|first=Sergiu|last2=Ganz|first2=Thomas|last3=Keilmann|first3=Fritz|date=2009-11-23|title=Mid-infrared near-field spectroscopy|url=https://www.osapublishing.org/oe/abstract.cfm?uri=oe-17-24-21794|journal=Optics Express|language=EN|volume=17|issue=24|doi=10.1364/oe.17.021794|issn=1094-4087|bibcode=2009OExpr..1721794A}}</ref> The detection of a single molecular complex<ref name=":3">{{Cite journal|last=Amenabar|first=Iban|last2=Poly|first2=Simon|last3=Nuansing|first3=Wiwat|last4=Hubrich|first4=Elmar H.|last5=Govyadinov|first5=Alexander A.|last6=Huth|first6=Florian|last7=Krutokhvostov|first7=Roman|last8=Zhang|first8=Lianbing|last9=Knez|first9=Mato|date=2013-12-04|year=|title=Structural analysis and mapping of individual protein complexes by infrared nanospectroscopy|url=http://www.nature.com/doifinder/10.1038/ncomms3890|journal=Nature Communications|language=en|volume=4|pages=|doi=10.1038/ncomms3890|issn=2041-1723|pmid=24301518|via=|bibcode=2013NatCo...4E2890A}}</ref> and the sensitivity to a single monolayer<ref name=":6">{{Cite journal|last=Xu|first=Xiaoji G.|last2=Rang|first2=Mathias|last3=Craig|first3=Ian M.|last4=Raschke|first4=Markus B.|date=2012-07-05|title=Pushing the Sample-Size Limit of Infrared Vibrational Nanospectroscopy: From Monolayer toward Single Molecule Sensitivity|url=https://dx.doi.org/10.1021/jz300463d|journal=The Journal of Physical Chemistry Letters|volume=3|issue=13|pages=1836–1841|doi=10.1021/jz300463d|issn=1948-7185}}</ref> has been shown. Recording infrared spectra as a function of position can be used for nanoscale mapping of the sample chemical composition,<ref name=":02">{{Cite journal|last=Huth|first=Florian|last2=Govyadinov|first2=Alexander|last3=Amarie|first3=Sergiu|last4=Nuansing|first4=Wiwat|last5=Keilmann|first5=Fritz|last6=Hillenbrand|first6=Rainer|date=2012-08-08|title=Nano-FTIR Absorption Spectroscopy of Molecular Fingerprints at 20 nm Spatial Resolution|url=https://dx.doi.org/10.1021/nl301159v|journal=Nano Letters|volume=12|issue=8|pages=3973–3978|doi=10.1021/nl301159v|issn=1530-6984|bibcode=2012NanoL..12.3973H}}</ref><ref name=":7">{{Cite journal|last=Ugarte|first=Lorena|last2=Santamaria-Echart|first2=Arantzazu|last3=Mastel|first3=Stefan|last4=Autore|first4=Marta|last5=Hillenbrand|first5=Rainer|last6=Corcuera|first6=Maria Angeles|last7=Eceiza|first7=Arantxa|date=2017-01-01|title=An alternative approach for the incorporation of cellulose nanocrystals in flexible polyurethane foams based on renewably sourced polyols|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0926669016307555|journal=Industrial Crops and Products|volume=95|pages=564–573|doi=10.1016/j.indcrop.2016.11.011}}</ref> performing a local ultrafast IR spectroscopy<ref name=":10" /> and analyzing the nanoscale intermolecular coupling,<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Pollard|first=Benjamin|last2=Muller|first2=Eric A.|last3=Hinrichs|first3=Karsten|last4=Raschke|first4=Markus B.|date=2014-04-11|year=|title=Vibrational nano-spectroscopic imaging correlating structure with intermolecular coupling and dynamics|url=http://www.nature.com/doifinder/10.1038/ncomms4587|journal=Nature Communications|language=en|volume=5|pages=|doi=10.1038/ncomms4587|issn=2041-1723|pmid=24721995|via=|bibcode=2014NatCo...5E3587P}}</ref> among others. A spatial resolution of 10 nm to 20 nm is routinely achieved<ref name=":02" /> [[File:Chemical ID with nano-FTIR.png|alt=chemical ID with nano-FTIR|thumb|342x342px|Nanoscale chemical identification with nano-FTIR: local spectroscopy performed by nano-FTIR allowed for chemical identification of a nanoscale contaminant – a [[Polydimethylsiloxane]] (PDMS) particle – adjacent to a [[Poly(methyl methacrylate)]] (PMMA) film.<ref name=":02" />]]For [[organic compound]]s, [[polymer]]s, [[Organic matter|biological]] and other [[soft matter]], nano-FTIR spectra can be directly compared to the standard FTIR databases, which allows for a straightforward chemical identification and characterization.<ref name=":02" />
Nano-FTIR does not require special sample preparation and is typically performed under ambient conditions. It uses an AFM operated in [[Non-contact atomic force microscopy|noncontact]] mode that is intrinsically nondestructive and sufficiently gentle to be suitable for [[Soft matter|soft-matter]] and [[biological]] sample investigations. Nano-FTIR can be utilized from [[Terahertz radiation|THz]] to [[Visible spectrum|visible]] spectral range (and not only in [[infrared]] as its name suggests) depending on the application requirements and availability of broadband sources. Nano-FTIR is complementary to [[Tip-enhanced Raman spectroscopy]] (TERS), [[Near-field scanning optical microscope|SNOM]], [[AFM-IR]] and other scanning probe methods that are capable of performing [[Vibrational analysis with scanning probe microscopy|vibrational analysis]].
== Basic principles == [[File:Near-field probing.png|alt=Principles of near-field probing|thumb|180x180px|Principles of near-field probing: the sample is analyzed via scattering from a sharp, externally illuminated probe]] Nano-FTIR is based on s-SNOM, where the infrared beam from a light source is focused onto a sharp, typically metalized AFM tip and the backscattering is detected. The tip greatly enhances the illuminating IR light in the nanoscopic volume around its apex, creating a strong near field. A sample, brought into this near field, interacts with the tip electromagnetically and modifies the tip (back)scattering in the process. Thus by detecting tip scattering, one can obtain information about the sample.
Nano-FTIR detects the tip-scattered light interferometrically. The sample stage is placed into one arm of a conventional [[Michelson interferometer]], while a mirror on a piezo stage is placed into another, reference arm. Recording the backscattered signal while translating the reference mirror yields an [[interferogram]]. The subsequent [[Fourier transform]] of this interferogram returns the near-field spectra of the sample. [[File:Nano-FTIR spectra of polyurethane obtained using neaSNOM.png|alt=nano-FTIR and ATR FTIR|thumb|341x341px|nano-FTIR absorption and far-field FTIR (ATR modality) spectra measured on the same polymer sample show great agreement.]] Placement of the sample stage into one of the interferometer's arms (instead of outside of the interferometer as typically implemented in [[Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy|conventional FTIR]]) is a key element of nano-FTIR. It boosts the weak near-field signal due to interference with the strong reference field, helps to eliminate completely the background caused by parasitic scattering off everything that falls into large diffraction-limited beam focus, and most importantly, allows for recording of both amplitude ''s'' and phase ''φ'' spectra of the tip-scattered radiation.<ref>{{cite thesis |type=Ph.D. |last=Huth |first=Florian |date=2015 |title=Nano-FTIR - Nanoscale Infrared Near-Field Spectroscopy |publisher=Universidad del Pais Vasco}}</ref> With the detection of phase, nano-FTIR provides complete information about near fields, which is essential for quantitative studies and many other applications. For example, for [[soft matter]] samples (organics, polymers, biomaterials, etc.), ''φ'' directly relates to the absorption in the sample material.<ref>{{Cite journal|date=2004-11-22|title=Nanoscale polymer recognition by spectral signature in scattering infrared near-field microscopy|url=http://aip.scitation.org/doi/10.1063/1.1827334|journal=Applied Physics Letters|volume=85|issue=21|pages=5064–5066|doi=10.1063/1.1827334|issn=0003-6951|bibcode=2004ApPhL..85.5064T}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Carney|first=P. Scott|last2=Deutsch|first2=Bradley|last3=Govyadinov|first3=Alexander A.|last4=Hillenbrand|first4=Rainer|date=2012-01-24|title=Phase in Nanooptics|url=https://dx.doi.org/10.1021/nn205008y|journal=ACS Nano|volume=6|issue=1|pages=8–12|doi=10.1021/nn205008y|issn=1936-0851}}</ref> This permits a direct comparison of nano-FTIR spectra with conventional [[Absorption spectroscopy|absorption spectra]] <nowiki/>of the sample material,<ref name=":02"/> thus allowing for simple spectroscopic identification according to standard FTIR databases.
== History == Nano-FTIR was first described in 2005 in a patent by Ocelic and Hillenbrand as Fourier transform spectroscopy of tip-scattered light with an asymmetric spectrometer (i.e. the tip/sample placed inside one of the interferometer arms).<ref name=":16">{{cite patent|country=WO|number=2007039210|title=Optical device for measuring modulated signal light|status=patent|pubdate=2007-04-12|fdate=2006-09-27|pridate=2005-09-30|gdate=|invent1=Nenad Ocelic|invent2=Rainer Hillenbrand|inventor1-first=|class=G01Q60/18}}</ref> The first realization of s-SNOM with FTIR was demonstrated in 2006 in the laboratory of F. Keilmann using a mid-infrared source based on a simple version of nonlinear difference-frequency generation (DFG).<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Brehm|first=Markus|last2=Schliesser|first2=Albert|last3=Keilmann|first3=Fritz|date=2006-11-13|title=Spectroscopic near-field microscopy using frequency combs in the mid-infrared|url=https://www.osapublishing.org/abstract.cfm?uri=oe-14-23-11222|journal=Optics Express|language=EN|volume=14|issue=23|pages=11222–11233|doi=10.1364/OE.14.011222|issn=1094-4087|bibcode=2006OExpr..1411222B}}</ref> However, the mid-IR spectra in this realization were recorded using dual comb spectroscopy principles,<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Keilmann|first=Fritz|last2=Gohle|first2=Christoph|last3=Holzwarth|first3=Ronald|date=2004-07-01|title=Time-domain mid-infrared frequency-comb spectrometer|url=https://www.osapublishing.org/abstract.cfm?uri=ol-29-13-1542|journal=Optics Letters|language=EN|volume=29|issue=13|pages=1542–1544|doi=10.1364/OL.29.001542|issn=1539-4794|bibcode=2004OptL...29.1542K}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Coddington|first=Ian|last2=Newbury|first2=Nathan|last3=Swann|first3=William|date=2016-04-20|title=Dual-comb spectroscopy|url=https://www.osapublishing.org/abstract.cfm?uri=optica-3-4-414|journal=Optica|language=EN|volume=3|issue=4|pages=414–426|doi=10.1364/OPTICA.3.000414|issn=2334-2536}}</ref> yielding a discrete set of frequencies and thus demonstrating a multiheterodyne imaging technique rather than nano-FTIR. The first continuous spectra were recorded only in 2009 in the same laboratory using a supercontinuum IR beam also obtained by DFG in GaSe upon superimposing two pulsed trains emitted from Er-doped fiber laser.<ref name=":11" /> This source further allowed in 2011 for the first assessment of nanoscale-resolved spectra of SiC with excellent quality and spectral resolution.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Amarie|first=S.|date=2011-01-01|title=Broadband-infrared assessment of phonon resonance in scattering-type near-field microscopy|url=http://link.aps.org/doi/10.1103/PhysRevB.83.045404|journal=Physical Review B|volume=83|issue=4|doi=10.1103/PhysRevB.83.045404|bibcode=2011PhRvB..83d5404A}}</ref> At the same time, Huth et al.<ref name=":4">{{Cite journal|last=Huth|first=F.|last2=Schnell|first2=M.|last3=Wittborn|first3=J.|last4=Ocelic|first4=N.|last5=Hillenbrand|first5=R.|year=2011|title=Infrared-spectroscopic nanoimaging with a thermal source|url=http://www.nature.com/doifinder/10.1038/nmat3006|journal=Nature Materials|volume=10|issue=5|pages=352–356|doi=10.1038/nmat3006|via=|bibcode=2011NatMa..10..352H}}</ref> in the laboratory of R. Hillenbrand used IR radiation from a simple [[Globar|glowbar]] source in combination with the principles of Fourier transform spectroscopy, to record IR spectra of p-doped Si and its oxides in a semiconductor device. In the same work the term nano-FTIR was first introduced. However, an insufficient [[spectral irradiance]] of glowbar sources limited the applicability of the technique to the detection of strongly-resonant excitations such phonons;<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Ishikawa|first=Michio|last2=Katsura|first2=Makoto|last3=Nakashima|first3=Satoru|last4=Ikemoto|first4=Yuka|last5=Okamura|first5=Hidekazu|date=2012-05-07|title=Broadband near-field mid-infrared spectroscopy and application to phonon resonances in quartz|url=https://www.osapublishing.org/oe/abstract.cfm?uri=oe-20-10-11064|journal=Optics Express|language=EN|volume=20|issue=10|doi=10.1364/oe.20.011064|issn=1094-4087|bibcode=2012OExpr..2011064I}}</ref> and the early supercontinuum IR laser sources, while providing more power, had very narrow bandwidth (<300 cm<sup>−1</sup>). Further attempt to improve the spectral power, while retaining the large bandwidth of a glowbar source was made by utilizing the IR radiation from a high temperature [[Electric arc|argon arc]] source (also known as plasma source).<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Huth|first=Florian|last2=Chuvilin|first2=Andrey|last3=Schnell|first3=Martin|last4=Amenabar|first4=Iban|last5=Krutokhvostov|first5=Roman|last6=Lopatin|first6=Sergei|last7=Hillenbrand|first7=Rainer|date=2013-03-13|title=Resonant Antenna Probes for Tip-Enhanced Infrared Near-Field Microscopy|url=https://dx.doi.org/10.1021/nl304289g|journal=Nano Letters|volume=13|issue=3|pages=1065–1072|doi=10.1021/nl304289g|issn=1530-6984|bibcode=2013NanoL..13.1065H}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=McIntosh|first=A. L|last2=Wofford|first2=B. A|last3=Lucchese|first3=R. R|last4=Bevan|first4=J. W|date=2001-12-01|title=High resolution Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy using a high temperature argon arc source|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S135044950100113X|journal=Infrared Physics & Technology|volume=42|issue=6|pages=509–514|doi=10.1016/S1350-4495(01)00113-X|bibcode=2001InPhT..42..509M}}</ref> However, due to lack of commercial availability and rapid development of the IR supercontinium laser sources, plasma sources are not widely utilized in nano-FTIR. [[File:Hyperspectral image of a copolymer blend.png|alt=hyperspectral nano-FTIR image|thumb|262x262px|Hyperspectral image of a copolymer blend acquired by nano-FTIR<ref>{{Cite Communications|language=en|volume=8|pages=|doi=10.1038/ncomms14402|issn=2041-1723|bibcode=2017NatCo...814402A}}</ref>]] The breakthrough in nano-FTIR came upon the development of high-power broadband journal|last=Hegenbarth|first=R|last2=Steinmann|first2=A|last3=Mastel|first3=S|last4=Amarie|first4=S|last5=Huber|first5=A J|last6=Hillenbrand|first6=R|last7=Sarkisov|first7=S Y|last8=Giessen|first8=H|year=2014|title=High-power femtosecond mid-IR sources for s-SNOM even the weakest vibrational resonances.<ref name=":02"/><ref name=":6" /><ref name=":3" /><ref name=":8">{{Cite journal|last=Bensmann|first=Stefanie|last2=Gaußmann|first2=Fabian|last3=Lewin|first3=Martin|last4=Wüppen|first4=Jochen|last5=Nyga|first5=Sebastian|last6=Janzen|first6=Christoph|last7=Jungbluth|first7=Bernd|last8=Taubner|first8=Thomas|date=2014-09-22|title=Near-field imaging and spectroscopy of locally strained GaN using an IR broadband laser|url=https://www.osapublishing.org/oe/abstract.cfm?uri=oe-22-19-22369|journal=Optics Express|language=EN|volume=22|issue=19|pages=|doi=10.1364/oe.22.022369|issn=1094-4087|via=|bibcode=2014OExpr..2222369B}}</ref> Particularly, it has been shown that nano-FTIR is capable of measuring Additional boost to the development of nano-FTIR came from the utilization of the [[synchrotron radiation]] that provide extreme bandwidth, yet at the expense of weaker IR spectral irradiance compared == Commercialization == [[File:Nano-FTIR integrated with s-SNOM.jpg|alt=Nano-FTIR integrated with s-SNOM (neaSNOM)|thumb|345x345px|Nano-FTIR integrated with s-SNOM ([http://www.neaspec.com/ neaSNOM]) with all three base components marked by arrows.]] The nano-FTIR technology has been commercialized by [http://www.neaspec.com neaspec] – a Germany-based spin-off company of the [[Max Planck Institute of Biochemistry]] founded by Ocelic, Hillenbrand and Keilmann in 2007 and based on the original patent by Ocelic and Hillenbrand.<ref name=":16" /> The detection module optimized for broadband illumination sources was first made available in 2010 as a part of the standard [http://www.neaspec.com/products/neasnom-microscope/ neaSNOM microscope system]. At this time, broadband IR-lasers have not been yet commercially available, however experimental broadband IR-lasers prove that the technology works perfect and that it has a huge application potential across many disciplines. The first nano-FTIR was commercially available in 2012 (supplied with still experimental broadband IR-laser sources), becoming the first commercial system for broadband infrared nano-spectroscopy. In 2015 neaspec develops and introduces Ultrafast nano-FTIR, the commercial version of ultrafast nano-spectroscopy. Ultrafast nano-FTIR is a ready-to-use upgrade for nano-FTIR to enable pump-probe nano-spectroscopy at best-in-class spatial resolution. The same year the development of a cryo-neaSNOM – the first system of its kind to enable nanoscale near-field imaging & spectroscopy at cryogenic temperatures – was announced.
== Advanced capabilities == === Synchrotron beamlines integration === Nano-FTIR systems can be easily integrated into [[synchrotron radiation]] beamlines. The use of synchrotron radiation allows for acquisition of an entire mid-infrared spectrum at once. Synchrotrons radiation has already been utilized in synchrotron infrared microscopectroscopy - the technique most widely used in biosciences, providing information on chemistry on microscales of virtually all biological specimens, like bone, plants, and other biological tissues.<ref>{{Cite book|url=http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/3527600906.mcb.200500021/abstract|title=Reviews in Cell Biology and Molecular Medicine|last=Marinkovic|first=Nebojsa S.|last2=Chance|first2=Mark R.|date=2006-01-01|publisher=Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA|isbn=9783527600908|language=en|doi=10.1002/3527600906.mcb.200500021}}</ref> Nano-FTIR brings the spatial resolution to 10-20 nm scale (vs. ~2-5 μm in microspectroscopy), which has been utilized for broadband spatially-resolved spectroscopy of crystalline<ref name=":23" /><ref name=":24" /> and phase-change<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Gilbert Corder|first=Stephanie N.|last2=Chen|first2=Xinzhong|last3=Zhang|first3=Shaoqing|last4=Hu|first4=Fengrui|last5=Zhang|first5=Jiawei|last6=Luan|first6=Yilong|last7=Logan|first7=Jack A.|last8=Ciavatti|first8=Thomas|last9=Bechtel|first9=Hans A.|date=2017-12-22|title=Near-field spectroscopic investigation of dual-band heavy fermion metamaterials|url=http://www.nature.com/articles/s41467-017-02378-3|journal=Nature Communications|language=En|volume=8|issue=1|doi=10.1038/s41467-017-02378-3|issn=2041-1723|bibcode=2017NatCo...8.2262G}}</ref> materials, semiconductors,<ref name=":9" /> minerals,<ref name=":0">{{Cite journal|last=Hao|first=Zhao|last2=Bechtel|first2=Hans A.|last3=Kneafsey|first3=Timothy|last4=Gilbert|first4=Benjamin|last5=Nico|first5=Peter S.|date=2018-02-07|title=Cross-Scale Molecular Analysis of Chemical Heterogeneity in Shale Rocks|url=http://www.nature.com/articles/s41598-018-20365-6|journal=Scientific Reports|language=En|volume=8|issue=1|doi=10.1038/s41598-018-20365-6|issn=2045-2322|bibcode=2018NatSR...8.2552H}}</ref> biominerals and proteins.<ref name=":5" />
=== Ultrafast spectroscopy === Nano-FTIR is highly suitable for performing local ultrafast pump-probe spectroscopy due to intereferometric detection and an intrinsic ability to vary the probe delay time. It has been applied for studies of ultrafast nanoscale plasmonic phenomena in Graphene,<ref name=":13">{{Cite journal|last=Wagner|first=Martin|last2=Fei|first2=Zhe|last3=McLeod|first3=Alexander S.|last4=Rodin|first4=Aleksandr S.|last5=Bao|first5=Wenzhong|last6=Iwinski|first6=Eric G.|last7=Zhao|first7=Zeng|last8=Goldflam|first8=Michael|last9=Liu|first9=Mengkun|date=2014-02-12|title=Ultrafast and Nanoscale Plasmonic Phenomena in Exfoliated Graphene Revealed by Infrared Pump–Probe Nanoscopy|url=https://dx.doi.org/10.1021/nl4042577|journal=Nano Letters|volume=14|issue=2|pages=894–900|doi=10.1021/nl4042577|issn=1530-6984|arxiv=1402.6003|bibcode=2014NanoL..14..894W}}</ref><ref name=":14">{{Cite journal|last=Ni|first=G. X.|last2=Wang|first2=L.|last3=Goldflam|first3=M. D.|last4=Wagner|first4=M.|last5=Fei|first5=Z.|last6=McLeod|first6=A. S.|last7=Liu|first7=M. K.|last8=Keilmann|first8=F.|last9=Özyilmaz|first9=B.|title=Ultrafast optical switching of infrared plasmon polaritons in high-mobility graphene|url=http://www.nature.com/doifinder/10.1038/nphoton.2016.45|journal=Nature Photonics|volume=10|issue=4|pages=244–247|doi=10.1038/nphoton.2016.45|bibcode=2016NaPho..10..244N}}</ref> for performing nanospectroscopy of InAs nanowires with subcycle resolution<ref name=":15">{{Cite journal|last=Eisele|first=M.|last2=Cocker|first2=T. L.|last3=Huber|first3=M. A.|last4=Plankl|first4=M.|last5=Viti|first5=L.|last6=Ercolani|first6=D.|last7=Sorba|first7=L.|last8=Vitiello|first8=M. S.|last9=Huber|first9=R.|title=Ultrafast multi-terahertz nano-spectroscopy with sub-cycle temporal resolution|url=http://www.nature.com/doifinder/10.1038/nphoton.2014.225|journal=Nature Photonics|volume=8|issue=11|pages=841–845|doi=10.1038/nphoton.2014.225|arxiv=1604.04304|bibcode=2014NaPho...8..841E}}</ref> and for probing the coherent vibrational dynamics of nanoscopic ensembles.<ref name=":10">{{Cite journal|last=Xu|first=Xiaoji G.|last2=Raschke|first2=Markus B.|date=2013-04-10|title=Near-Field Infrared Vibrational Dynamics and Tip-Enhanced Decoherence|url=https://dx.doi.org/10.1021/nl304804p|journal=Nano Letters|volume=13|issue=4|pages=1588–1595|doi=10.1021/nl304804p|issn=1530-6984|bibcode=2013NanoL..13.1588X}}</ref>
=== Quantitative studies === The availability of both amplitude and phase of the scattered field measured in nano-FTIR allows for the recovery of both real and imaginary parts of the dielectric function, i.e. finding the index of refraction and the extinction coefficient of the sample.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Tranca|first=D. E.|last2=Stanciu|first2=S. G.|last3=Hristu|first3=R.|last4=Stoichita|first4=C.|last5=Tofail|first5=S. A. M.|last6=Stanciu|first6=G. A.|date=2015-07-03|year=|title=High-resolution quantitative determination of dielectric function by using scattering scanning near-field optical microscopy|url=http://www.nature.com/articles/srep11876|journal=Scientific Reports|language=en|volume=5|pages=|doi=10.1038/srep11876|issn=2045-2322|pmid=26138665|via=|bibcode=2015NatSR...511876T}}</ref> While such recovery for arbitrarily-shaped samples or samples exhibiting collective excitations, such as phonons, requires a resource-demanding numerical optimization, for soft matter samples (polymers, biological matter and other organic materials) the recovery of the dielectric function could often be performed in real time using fast semi-analytical approaches. One of such approaches is based on the Taylor expansion of the scattered field with respect to a small parameter that isolates the dielectric properties of the sample and allows for a polynomial representation of measured near-field contrast. With an adequate tip-sample interaction model<ref name=":25">{{Cite journal|last=Cvitkovic|first=A.|last2=Ocelic|first2=N.|last3=Hillenbrand|first3=R.|date=2007-07-09|title=Analytical model for quantitative prediction of material contrasts in scattering-type near-field optical microscopy|url=https://www.osapublishing.org/oe/abstract.cfm?uri=oe-15-14-8550|journal=Optics Express|language=EN|volume=15|issue=14|doi=10.1364/oe.15.008550|issn=1094-4087|bibcode=2007OExpr..15.8550C}}</ref> and with known measurement parameters (e.g. tapping amplitude, demodulation order, reference material, etc.), the sample permittivity <math>\epsilon(\omega)</math> can be determined as a solution of a simple polynomial equation<ref name=":122">{{Cite journal|last=Govyadinov|first=Alexander A.|last2=Amenabar|first2=Iban|last3=Huth|first3=Florian|last4=Carney|first4=P. Scott|last5=Hillenbrand|first5=Rainer|date=2013-05-02|title=Quantitative Measurement of Local Infrared Absorption and Dielectric Function with Tip-Enhanced Near-Field Microscopy|url=https://dx.doi.org/10.1021/jz400453r|journal=The Journal of Physical Chemistry Letters|volume=4|issue=9|pages=1526–1531|doi=10.1021/jz400453r|issn=1948-7185}}</ref>
=== Subsurface analysis === Near-field methods, including nano-FTIR, are typically viewed as a technique for surface studies due to short probing ranges of about couple tip radii (~20-50 nm). However it has been demonstrated that within such probing ranges, s-SNOM is capable of detecting subsurface features and sample extents,<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Taubner|first=T.|last2=Keilmann|first2=F.|last3=Hillenbrand|first3=R.|date=2005-10-31|title=Nanoscale-resolved subsurface imaging by scattering-type near-field optical microscopy|url=https://www.osapublishing.org/oe/abstract.cfm?uri=oe-13-22-8893|journal=Optics Express|language=EN|volume=13|issue=22|doi=10.1364/opex.13.008893|issn=1094-4087|bibcode=2005OExpr..13.8893T}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Jung|first=Lena|last2=Hauer|first2=Benedikt|last3=Li|first3=Peining|last4=Bornhöfft|first4=Manuel|last5=Mayer|first5=Joachim|last6=Taubner|first6=Thomas|date=2016-03-07|title=Exploring the detection limits of infrared near-field microscopy regarding small buried structures and pushing them by exploiting superlens-related effects|url=https://www.osapublishing.org/abstract.cfm?URI=oe-24-5-4431|journal=Optics Express|language=EN|volume=24|issue=5|doi=10.1364/oe.24.004431|issn=1094-4087|bibcode=2016OExpr..24.4431J}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Krutokhvostov|first=Roman|last2=Govyadinov|first2=Alexander A.|last3=Stiegler|first3=Johannes M.|last4=Huth|first4=Florian|last5=Chuvilin|first5=Andrey|last6=Carney|first6=P. Scott|last7=Hillenbrand|first7=Rainer|date=2012-01-02|title=Enhanced resolution in subsurface near-field optical microscopy|url=https://www.osapublishing.org/oe/abstract.cfm?uri=oe-20-1-593|journal=Optics Express|language=EN|volume=20|issue=1|doi=10.1364/oe.20.000593|issn=1094-4087|bibcode=2012OExpr..20..593K}}</ref><ref name=":26">{{Cite journal|last=Zhang|first=L. M.|date=2012-01-01|title=Near-field spectroscopy of silicon dioxide thin films|url=http://link.aps.org/doi/10.1103/PhysRevB.85.075419|journal=Physical Review B|volume=85|issue=7|doi=10.1103/PhysRevB.85.075419|arxiv=1110.4927|bibcode=2012PhRvB..85g5419Z}}</ref> which could be used for the investigations of samples capped by thin protective layers,<ref>{{Cite journal|date=2015-10-12|title=Imaging of phase change materials below a capping layer using correlative infrared near-field microscopy and electron microscopy|url=http://aip.scitation.org/doi/10.1063/1.4933102|journal=Applied Physics Letters|volume=107|issue=15|pages=151902|doi=10.1063/1.4933102|issn=0003-6951|bibcode=2015ApPhL.107o1902L}}</ref> among others.
The detection of both near-field amplitude and phase also provides means for the quantitative studies of the sample interior (within the probing range of the tip near field, of course). This could been utilized for the recovery of thickness and permittivity of layered films and nanostructures,<ref name=":1">{{Cite journal|last=Govyadinov|first=Alexander A.|last2=Mastel|first2=Stefan|last3=Golmar|first3=Federico|last4=Chuvilin|first4=Andrey|last5=Carney|first5=P. Scott|last6=Hillenbrand|first6=Rainer|date=2014-07-22|title=Recovery of Permittivity and Depth from Near-Field Data as a Step toward Infrared Nanotomography|url=https://dx.doi.org/10.1021/nn5016314|journal=ACS Nano|volume=8|issue=7|pages=6911–6921|doi=10.1021/nn5016314|issn=1936-0851}}</ref> for the nanoscale profiling of multiphase materials<ref name=":18">{{Cite journal|last=Lucas|first=I. T.|last2=McLeod|first2=A. S.|last3=Syzdek|first3=J. S.|last4=Middlemiss|first4=D. S.|last5=Grey|first5=C. P.|last6=Basov|first6=D. N.|last7=Kostecki|first7=R.|date=2015-01-14|title=IR Near-Field Spectroscopy and Imaging of Single LixFePO4 Microcrystals|url=https://dx.doi.org/10.1021/nl5010898|journal=Nano Letters|volume=15|issue=1|pages=1–7|doi=10.1021/nl5010898|issn=1530-6984|bibcode=2015NanoL..15....1L}}</ref> and other subsurface analysis of samples.<ref name=":19">{{Cite journal|last=Gozar|first=A.|last2=Litombe|first2=N. E.|last3=Hoffman|first3=Jennifer E.|last4=Božović|first4=I.|date=2017-03-08|title=Optical Nanoscopy of High Tc Cuprate Nanoconstriction Devices Patterned by Helium Ion Beams|url=https://dx.doi.org/10.1021/acs.nanolett.6b04729|journal=Nano Letters|volume=17|issue=3|pages=1582–1586|doi=10.1021/acs.nanolett.6b04729|issn=1530-6984|arxiv=1703.02101|bibcode=2017NanoL..17.1582G}}</ref> In other words, nano-FTIR has a unique capability of recovering the same information about thin-film samples that is typically returned by [[ellipsometry]] or [[impedance spectroscopy]], yet with nanoscale spatial resolution.
=== Operation in liquid === Nano-FTIR uses scattered IR light to obtain information about the sample and therefore, has the potential of investigating biological (or other) samples in their natural environment, such as water. The feasibility of such investigation has already been shown via imaging through a capping [[Graphene]] layer (using the same s-SNOM platform that nano-FTIR utilizes).<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Khatib|first=Omar|last2=Wood|first2=Joshua D.|last3=McLeod|first3=Alexander S.|last4=Goldflam|first4=Michael D.|last5=Wagner|first5=Martin|last6=Damhorst|first6=Gregory L.|last7=Koepke|first7=Justin C.|last8=Doidge|first8=Gregory P.|last9=Rangarajan|first9=Aniruddh|date=2015-08-25|title=Graphene-Based Platform for Infrared Near-Field Nanospectroscopy of Water and Biological Materials in an Aqueous Environment|url=https://dx.doi.org/10.1021/acsnano.5b01184|journal=ACS Nano|volume=9|issue=8|pages=7968–7975|doi=10.1021/acsnano.5b01184|issn=1936-0851|arxiv=1509.01743}}</ref>
=== Cryogenic environment === Reveling the fundamentals of [[phase transition]]s in superconductors, correlated oxides, [[Bose–Einstein condensate|Bose-Einstein condensates]] of surface polaritons, etc. require spectroscopic studies at the characteristically nanometer length scales and in cryogenic environment. Nano-FTIR is compatible with cryogenic s-SNOM that has already been utilized for reveling a nanotextured coexistence of metal and correlated Mott insulator phases in Vanadium oxide near the metal-insulator transition.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=McLeod|first=A. S.|last2=Heumen|first2=E. van|last3=Ramirez|first3=J. G.|last4=Wang|first4=S.|last5=Saerbeck|first5=T.|last6=Guenon|first6=S.|last7=Goldflam|first7=M.|last8=Anderegg|first8=L.|last9=Kelly|first9=P.|title=Nanotextured phase coexistence in the correlated insulator V2O3|url=http://www.nature.com/doifinder/10.1038/nphys3882|journal=Nature Physics|volume=13|issue=1|pages=80–86|doi=10.1038/nphys3882|bibcode=2017NatPh..13...80M}}</ref>
=== Special atmosphere environments === Nano-FTIR can be operated is different atmospheric environments by enclosing the system into an isolated chamber or a glove box. Such operation has already been used for the investigation of highly reactive [[Lithium-ion battery]] components.<ref name=":18" />
== Applications == Nano-FTIR has a plenitude of applications,<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Muller|first=Eric A.|last2=Pollard|first2=Benjamin|last3=Raschke|first3=Markus B.|date=2015-04-02|title=Infrared Chemical Nano-Imaging: Accessing Structure, Coupling, and Dynamics on Molecular Length Scales|url=https://dx.doi.org/10.1021/acs.jpclett.5b00108|journal=The Journal of Physical Chemistry Letters|volume=6|issue=7|pages=1275–1284|doi=10.1021/acs.jpclett.5b00108|issn=1948-7185}}</ref> including polymers and polymer composites,<ref name=":02"/> organic films,<ref name=":20">{{Cite journal|last=Westermeier|first=Christian|last2=Cernescu|first2=Adrian|last3=Amarie|first3=Sergiu|last4=Liewald|first4=Clemens|last5=Keilmann|first5=Fritz|last6=Nickel|first6=Bert|date=2014-06-11|year=|title=Sub-micron phase coexistence in small-molecule organic thin films revealed by infrared nano-imaging|url=http://www.nature.com/doifinder/10.1038/ncomms5101|journal=Nature Communications|language=en|volume=5|pages=|doi=10.1038/ncomms5101|issn=2041-1723|pmid=24916130|via=|bibcode=2014NatCo...5E4101W}}</ref> semiconductors,<ref name=":4" /><ref name=":5" /><ref name=":9" /><ref name=":19" /> biological research (cell membranes, proteins structure, studies of single viruses),<ref name=":3" /><ref name=":5" /><ref name=":21">{{Cite journal|last=Amarie|first=Sergiu|last2=Zaslansky|first2=Paul|last3=Kajihara|first3=Yusuke|last4=Griesshaber|first4=Erika|last5=Schmahl|first5=Wolfgang W|last6=Keilmann|first6=Fritz|date=2012-04-05|year=|title=Nano-FTIR chemical mapping of minerals in biological materials|url=http://www.beilstein-journals.org/bjnano/content/3/1/35|journal=Beilstein Journal of Nanotechnology|language=en|volume=3|issue=1|pages=312–323|doi=10.3762/bjnano.3.35|pmid=22563528|via=}}</ref> chemistry and catalysis,<ref name=":22">{{Cite journal|last=Wu|first=Chung-Yeh|last2=Wolf|first2=William J.|last3=Levartovsky|first3=Yehonatan|last4=Bechtel|first4=Hans A.|last5=Martin|first5=Michael C.|last6=Toste|first6=F. Dean|last7=Gross|first7=Elad|date=2017-01-26|title=High-spatial-resolution mapping of catalytic reactions on single particles|url=http://www.nature.com/nature/journal/v541/n7638/full/nature20795.html|journal=Nature|language=en|volume=541|issue=7638|pages=511–515|doi=10.1038/nature20795|issn=0028-0836|bibcode=2017Natur.541..511W}}</ref> photochemistry,<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Chen|first=Wenrui|last2=Qing|first2=Guangyan|last3=Sun|first3=Taolei|date=2016-12-22|title=A novel aggregation-induced emission enhancement triggered by the assembly of a chiral gelator: from non-emissive nanofibers to emissive micro-loops|url=http://xlink.rsc.org/?DOI=C6CC08808B|journal=Chem. Commun.|language=en|volume=53|issue=2|pages=447–450|doi=10.1039/c6cc08808b|issn=1364-548X}}</ref> minerals and biominerals,<ref name=":21" /><ref name=":5" /><ref name=":0" /> geochemistry,<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Dominguez|first=Gerardo|last2=Mcleod|first2=A. S.|last3=Gainsforth|first3=Zack|last4=Kelly|first4=P.|last5=Bechtel|first5=Hans A.|last6=Keilmann|first6=Fritz|last7=Westphal|first7=Andrew|last8=Thiemens|first8=Mark|last9=Basov|first9=D. N.|date=2014-12-09|title=Nanoscale infrared spectroscopy as a non-destructive probe of extraterrestrial samples|url=http://www.nature.com/doifinder/10.1038/ncomms6445|journal=Nature Communications|language=en|volume=5|doi=10.1038/ncomms6445|issn=2041-1723|bibcode=2014NatCo...5E5445D}}</ref> corrosion<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Johnson|first=C. Magnus|last2=Böhmler|first2=Miriam|date=2016-07-01|title=Nano-FTIR microscopy and spectroscopy studies of atmospheric corrosion with a spatial resolution of 20 nm|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0010938X16300804|journal=Corrosion Science|volume=108|pages=60–65|doi=10.1016/j.corsci.2016.02.037}}</ref> and materials sciences,<ref name=":7" /><ref name=":8" /> low-dimensional materials,<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Dai|first=S.|last2=Fei|first2=Z.|last3=Ma|first3=Q.|last4=Rodin|first4=A. S.|last5=Wagner|first5=M.|last6=McLeod|first6=A. S.|last7=Liu|first7=M. K.|last8=Gannett|first8=W.|last9=Regan|first9=W.|date=2014-03-07|title=Tunable Phonon Polaritons in Atomically Thin van der Waals Crystals of Boron Nitride|url=http://science.sciencemag.org/content/343/6175/1125|journal=Science|language=en|volume=343|issue=6175|pages=1125–1129|doi=10.1126/science.1246833|issn=0036-8075|pmid=24604197|bibcode=2014Sci...343.1125D}}</ref><ref name=":14"/> photonics,<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Li|first=Peining|last2=Lewin|first2=Martin|last3=Kretinin|first3=Andrey V.|last4=Caldwell|first4=Joshua D.|last5=Novoselov|first5=Kostya S.|last6=Taniguchi|first6=Takashi|last7=Watanabe|first7=Kenji|last8=Gaussmann|first8=Fabian|last9=Taubner|first9=Thomas|date=2015-06-26|year=|title=Hyperbolic phonon-polaritons in boron nitride for near-field optical imaging and focusing|url=http://www.nature.com/articles/ncomms8507?WT.ec_id=NCOMMS-20150701|journal=Nature Communications|language=en|volume=6|pages=|doi=10.1038/ncomms8507|issn=2041-1723|pmid=26112474|via=|arxiv=1502.04093|bibcode=2015NatCo...6E7507L}}</ref><ref name=":5" /> energy storage,<ref name=":18" /> cosmetics, pharmacology and environmental sciences<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Pletikapić|first=G.|last2=Ivošević DeNardis|first2=N.|date=2017-01-06|title=Application of surface analytical methods for hazardous situation in the Adriatic Sea: monitoring of organic matter dynamics and oil pollution|url=http://www.nat-hazards-earth-syst-sci.net/17/31/2017/|journal=Nat. Hazards Earth Syst. Sci.|volume=17|issue=1|pages=31–44|doi=10.5194/nhess-17-31-2017|issn=1684-9981|bibcode=2017NHESS..17...31P}}</ref>
=== Materials and chemical sciences === Nano-FTIR has been used for the nanoscale spectroscopic chemical identification of polymers<ref name=":02"/> and nanocomposites,<ref name=":17" /> for ''in situ'' investigation of structure and crystallinity of organic thin films,<ref name=":20" /> for strain characterization and relaxation in crystalline materials<ref name=":8" /> and for high-resolution spatial mapping of catalytic reactions,<ref name=":22" /> among others.
=== Biological and pharmaceutical sciences === Nano-FTIR has been used for investigation of protein secondary structure, bacterial membrane,<ref name=":5" /> detection and studies of single viruses and protein complexes.<ref name=":5" /> It has been applied to the detection of biominerals in bone tissue.<ref name=":21" /><ref name=":5" />
=== Semiconductor industry and research === Nano-FTIR has been used for nanoscale free carrier profiling and quantification of free carrier concentration in semiconductor devices.,<ref name=":4" /> for evaluation of ion beam damage in nanoconstriction devices,<ref name=":19" /> and general spectroscopic characterization of semiconductor materials<ref name=":9" />
== Theory == ===High-harmonic demodulation for background suppression=== The nano-FTIR interferometrically detects light scattered from the tip-sample system, <math>E_{\rm sca}</math>. The power at the detector can be written as<ref>{{Cite journal|date=2006-09-04|title=Pseudoheterodyne detection for background-free near-field spectroscopy|url=http://aip.scitation.org/doi/10.1063/1.2348781|journal=Applied Physics Letters|volume=89|issue=10|pages=101124|doi=10.1063/1.2348781|issn=0003-6951|bibcode=2006ApPhL..89j1124O}}</ref>
<math>I_{\rm det}=|E_{\rm sca}+E_{\rm ref}|^2</math>
where <math>E_{\rm ref}</math>is the reference field. The scattered field can be written as
<math>E_{\rm sca}=E_{\rm bg}+E_{\rm nf}</math>
and is dominated by parasitic background scattering, <math>E_{\rm bg}</math>, from the tip shaft, cantilever sample roughness and everything else which falls into the [[Diffraction limited beam|diffraction-limited beam]] focus. To extract the near-field signal, <math>E_{\rm nf}</math>, originating from the "hot-spot" below the tip apex (which carries the nanoscale-resolved information about the sample properties) a small harmonic modulation of the tip height ''H'' (i.e. oscillating the tip) with frequency ''Ω'' is provided and the detector signal is demodulated at higher harmonics of this frequency n''Ω'' with n=1,2,3,4,... The background is nearly insensitive to small variations of the tip height and is nearly completely eliminated for sufficiently high demodulation orders (typically <math>n\ge 2</math>). Mathematically this can be shown by expanding <math>E_{\rm bg}</math> and <math>E_{\rm nf}</math> into a Fourier series, which yields the following (approximated) expression for the demodulated detector signal:
<math>I_{n} \propto E_{\rm ref}^*E_{\rm nf,n}+E_{\rm bg,0}^*E_{\rm nf,n}+{\rm C.C.}</math>
where <math>I_{n}=s_n {\rm e}^{{\rm i}\phi_n}</math>is the complex-valued number that is obtained by combining the lock-in amplitude, <math>s_n</math>, and phase, <math>\phi_n</math>, signals, <math>E_{\rm nf,n}</math>is the ''n''-th Fourier coefficient of the near-field contribution and C. C. stands for the complex conjugate terms. <math>E_{\rm bg,0}</math>is the zeroth-order Fourier coefficient of the background contribution and is often called the multiplicative background because it enters the detector signal as a product with <math>E_{\rm nf,n}</math>. It cannot be removed by the high-harmonic demodulation alone. In nano-FTIR the multiplicative background is completely eliminated as described below.
=== Asymmetric FTIR spectrometer === To acquire a spectrum, the reference mirror is continuously translated while recording the demodulated detector signal as a function of the reference mirror position <math>x</math>, yielding an interferogram <math>I_n(x)</math>. This way the phase of the reference field changes according to <math>\phi_{\rm ref}=x\omega/c</math> for each spectral component of the reference field <math>\omega</math> and the detector signal can thus be written as<ref>{{cite thesis|last=Huth|first=Florian|title=Nano-FTIR - Nanoscale Infrared Near-Field Spectroscopy|date=2015|publisher=Universidad del Pais Vasco|type=Ph.D.}}</ref>
<math>I_n(x)\propto \int {\rm d}\omega\left(E_{\rm ref,0}^*E_{{\rm nf},n}{\rm e}^{-{\rm i}x\omega/c}+E_{\rm bg,0}^*E_{{\rm nf},n}+{\rm C.C.}\right) </math>
where <math>E_{\rm ref,0}</math> is the reference field at zero delay <math>x=0</math>. To obtain the nano-FTIR spectrum, <math>\tilde{I}_n(\omega)</math>, the interferogram <math>I_n(x)</math> is Fourier-transformed with respect to <math>x</math>. The second term in the above equation does not depend on the reference mirror position and after the Fourier transformation contributes only to the DC signal. Thus for <math>\omega>0</math> only the near-field contribution multiplied by the reference field stays in the acquired spectrum:
<math>\tilde{I}_n(\omega)\propto E_{\rm ref,0}^*E_{{\rm nf},n} </math>
This way, besides providing the interferometric gain, the asymmetric interferometer utilized in nano-FTIR also completely eliminates the multiplicative background, which otherwise could be a source of various artifacts and is often overlooked in other s-SNOM based spectroscopies.
=== Normalization === Following the standard FTIR practice, spectra in nano-FTIR are normalized to those obtained on a known, preferably spectrally-flat reference material. This eliminates the generally unknown reference field and any instrumental functions, yielding spectra of the near-field contrast:
<math>\eta_n(\omega)=\frac{\tilde{I}_n(\omega)}{\tilde{I}_n^{\rm ref}(\omega)}=\frac{E_{{\rm nf},n}(\omega)}{E_{{\rm nf},n}^{\rm ref}(\omega)}</math>
Near-field contrast spectra are generally complex-valued, reflecting on the possible phase delay of the sample-scattered field with respect to the reference. Near-field contrast spectra depend nearly exclusively on the dielectric properties of sample material and can be used for its identification and characterization.
=== Nano-FTIR absorption spectroscopy === For the purpose of describing near-field contrasts for optically-thin samples composed of polymers, organics, biological matter and other soft matter (so called weak oscillators), the near-field signal to a good approximation can be expressed as.:<ref name=":122"/>
<math>\eta_n\propto \beta(\omega)</math>,
where <math>\beta=(\epsilon-1)/(\epsilon+1)</math>is the surface response function that depends on the complex-valued dielectric function <math>\epsilon(\omega)</math> of the sample and can be also viewed as the reflection coefficient for evanescent waves that constitute the near field of the tip. That is, the spectral dependence of <math>\eta_n(\omega)</math> is determined exclusively by the sample reflection coefficient. The latter is purely real and acquires an imaginary part only in narrow spectral regions around the sample absorption lines[4]. This means that the spectrum of an imaginary part of the near-field contrast resembles the conventional FTIR [[absorbance]] spectrum, <math>A(\omega)</math>, of the sample material:<ref name=":02"/><math display="inline">{\rm Im}[\sigma(\omega)]\propto A(\omega)</math>. It is therefore convenient to define the nano-FTIR absorption <math>a={\rm Im}(\eta_n)=s_n \sin(\phi_n)</math>, which directly relates to the sample absorbance spectrum:
<math>a(\omega)\propto A(\omega)</math>
It can be used for direct sample identification and characterization according to the standard FTIR databases without the need of modeling the tip-sample interaction.
For phononic and plasmonic samples in the vicinity of the corresponding surface surface resonances, the relation <math>\eta_n(\omega)=\beta(\omega)</math> might not hold. In such cases the simple relation between <math>a(\omega)</math> and <math>A(\omega)</math> can not be obtained, requiring modeling of the tip-sample interaction for spectroscopic identification of such samples<ref name=":26"/>
== References == {{reflist|30em}}
